In order to determine whether this argument is logically valid, we need to evaluate whether the conclusion logically follows from the premise.

1. Identify the contrapositive of the premise: The contrapositive of "If the dog was inside, then the cat was outside" is "If the cat was not outside, then the dog was not inside".

Check if the negated conclusion is equivalent to the contrapositive of the premise: As we can see, the negated conclusion "If the cat was not outside, then the dog was not inside" is indeed equivalent to the contrapositive of the premise "If the cat was not outside, then the dog was not inside".

Therefore, since the negated conclusion is equivalent to the contrapositive of the premise, the argument is logically valid.
